Can-do statement.0: Can use 'and' to join a limited range of common adjectives.
Can-do statement.1: Can use 'but' to join a limited range of common adjectives, after 'be'.
Can-do statement.2: Can use a comma to combine two adjectives used before the noun, following the usual order of adjective types.
Can-do statement.3: Can use 'and' to join a limited range of comparative adjectives.► adjectives: comparatives
Can-do statement.4: Can use commas and 'and' to join more than two adjectives, after 'be'.
Can-do statement.5: Can use 'and' to repeat a comparative adjective to indicate change over time, usually after 'become' or get. ► adjectives: comparatives
Can-do statement.6: Can use a limited range of compound adjectives ('good-looking', 'well-known')
Can-do statement.7: Can use an increasing range of compound adjectives ('up-to-date', 'state-of-the-art')
Can-do statement.8: Can use adjective phrases to modify nouns.
Can-do statement.9: Can use a wide range of compound adjectives ('open-minded', 'above-mentioned', 'well-to-do', 'jaw-dropping')
Can-do statement.10: Can combine more complex, lengthy strings of adjectives, joining the last two adjectives with 'and'.
Can-do statement.11: Can use a list of adjectives in ellipted clauses before and after a noun, to give focus. ► focus
Can-do statement.12: Can form comparative adjectives from adjectives of one syllable by adding '-er'.
Can-do statement.13: Can form comparative adjectives with adjectives of two syllables ending in '-y' by changing the 'y' to an 'I' and adding '-er'.
Can-do statement.14: Can use comparative adjectives attributively, before nouns.
Can-do statement.15: Can use comparative adjectives as a complement of 'be'.
Can-do statement.16: Can form comparative adjectives with adjectives of one syllable with a short vowel, by doubling the final consonant and adding '-er'
Can-do statement.17: Can form comparative adjectives with adjectives of one syllable ending in 'e', by adding '-r'.
Can-do statement.19: Can form a range of comparative adjective phrases using 'more' + longer adjectives (usually three or more syllables).
Can-do statement.20: Can use a comparative adjective with 'than' to compare two nouns or noun phrases.► comparative clauses
Can-do statement.21: Can use '(so) much' to modify and intensify comparative adjectives used predicatively after a verb, usually 'be'.
Can-do statement.22: Can use 'a (little) bit' to modify comparative adjectives used predicatively after a verb, usually 'be'.
Can-do statement.23: Can use 'and' to repeat a comparative adjective to indicate change over time, usually after 'become' or 'get'.  ► adjectives: comparatives
Can-do statement.24: Can use 'even' to modify and intensify comparative adjectives used predicatively after a verb, usually 'be' and 'get'.
Can-do statement.25: Can use 'a lot' to modify and intensify comparative adjectives used predicatively after a verb, usually 'be'.
Can-do statement.26: Can use 'much' to modify and intensify comparative adjectives used attributively before countable and uncountable nouns.
Can-do statement.27: Can use 'slightly' to modify comparative adjectives to a small degree.
Can-do statement.28: Can use 'no' / 'not any' with comparative adjectives to limit the scale of comparison. ► comparative clauses
Can-do statement.29: Can use 'not that much' to modify comparative adjectives to a small degree. ► comparative clauses
Can-do statement.30: Can use 'very' with a limited range of common gradable adjectives.
Can-do statement.31: Can use adverbs of degree ('really', 'so', 'quite') with an increasing range of common gradable adjectives.
Can-do statement.32: Can form adjective phrases with a very limited range of adjectives + a prepositional phrase.
Can-do statement.33: Can use 'too' with common gradable adjectives.
Can-do statement.35: Can use adjective phrases attributively, before a noun.
Can-do statement.37: Can form adjective phrases with 'quite a' + adjective.
Can-do statement.38: Can use 'too' before adjectives followed by 'to'-infinitive.
Can-do statement.39: Can use 'enough' after adjectives followed by 'to'-infinitive
Can-do statement.40: Can form adjective phrases with 'rather a' + adjective, often in formal contexts.
Can-do statement.41: Can modify gradable adjectives with extreme adverbs of degree ('absolutely', 'extremely', 'incredibly', 'totally') to intensify their meaning.
Can-do statement.42: Can use adjectives in 'as … as' and 'so … that' in comparative structures. ► comparative clauses
Can-do statement.43: Can use a limited range of adjectives attributively, before a noun. ► noun phrases
Can-do statement.44: Can use a limited range of adjectives predicatively, after 'be'.
Can-do statement.45: Can use a limited range of adjectives ('main', 'only') that limit the noun that they go before.
Can-do statement.46: Can use an increasing range of adjectives predicatively, after 'be'.
Can-do statement.47: Can use a limited range of adjectives predicatively, after linking verbs 'look' and 'feel'.
Can-do statement.48: Can use adjectives with the prefix a- ('asleep', 'awake', 'alive', 'alone') predicatively only, after linking verbs.
Can-do statement.49:
Can use an increasing range of adjectives attributively, before a noun.
► noun phrases
Can-do statement.50: Can use adjectives as object complement after 'make'.
Can-do statement.51: Can use an adjective or adjective phrase after pronouns like 'something', 'nothing', 'somewhere', 'nowhere'.
Can-do statement.52: Can use a limited range of degree adjectives ('real', 'absolute', 'complete') before a noun to express intensity.
Can-do statement.53: Can use the adjectives 'present', 'future', 'former' before a noun.
Can-do statement.54: Can use the '–ed' form of a verb as an adjective, after a noun.
Can-do statement.55: Can use an increasing range of adjectives before a noun to express intensity.
Can-do statement.56: Can use the irregular superlative adjective 'best' in the phrase 'my best friend'.
Can-do statement.57: Can form a limited range of complex noun phrases with a superlative adjective  + prepositional phrase, to talk about something unique.► noun phrases ►  clauses: comparison
Can-do statement.58: Can use prepositional phrases with 'in' + singular name of a place after a superlative adjective.
Can-do statement.59: Can use a limited range of prepositional phrases with 'of' after a superlative adjective, to refer to one thing within a set or part of a set.
Can-do statement.60: Can use 'the' with a limited range of superlative adjectives without a following noun, when the noun is understood.
Can-do statement.61: Can form superlative adjectives with adjectives of one syllable with a short vowel, by doubling the final consonant and adding '–est'.
Can-do statement.62: Can form superlative adjectives by adding the suffix '-est', to adjectives of one syllable.
Can-do statement.63: Can form superlative adjectives using the '-est' suffix, with adjectives of one syllable, and with two-syllable adjectives ending in -y.
Can-do statement.64: Can form a noun phrase with 'my' or 'your' + superlative adjective + noun, with a limited range of nouns and contexts. ► noun phrases
Can-do statement.65: Can form superlative adjectives using the suffix '-st' to adjectives ending in '–e'.
Can-do statement.66: Can form a noun phrase with 'the' + superlative adjective + noun. ► noun phrases
Can-do statement.67: Can form superlative adjective phrases using 'the most', with longer adjectives of two or more syllables.
Can-do statement.68: Can form an increasing range of complex noun phrases with a superlative adjective + prepositional phrase, to talk about something unique. ► noun phrases
Can-do statement.69: Can use 'the best' before a noun + present perfect to talk about a unique experience.
Can-do statement.70: Can use 'one of the' before a superlative adjective, followed by a plural noun. ► noun phrases
Can-do statement.71: Can use 'the best' before a noun + 'to'-infinitive.  ► clauses: comparative
Can-do statement.72: Can form noun phrases with a range of determiners before a superlative adjective. ► noun phrases
Can-do statement.73: Can use the premodifer 'by far' to make a superlative adjective stronger.
Can-do statement.74: Can use '(one of) the' with an increasing range of superlative adjectives without a following noun, when the noun is understood.
Can-do statement.75: Can use superlative adjectives before a noun + 'to'-infinitive. ► clauses: comparative
Can-do statement.76: Can use a postmodifier to make the superlative stronger in the structure superlative + postmodifier + noun.
Can-do statement.77: Can use a postmodifier to make the superlative stronger, in the structure superlative + noun + postmodifier ('possible', 'ever', 'by far').
Can-do statement.78: Can use 'the slightest', 'the faintest' with a specific range of nouns to express the least amount possible, most frequently following a negative verb form.
Can-do statement.79: Can use 'soon' in the phrases 'See you soon' and 'Get well soon', as a signing-off device.
Can-do statement.80: Can use a limited range of adverbs ('here', 'there') to indicate place.
Can-do statement.81: Can use a limited range of adverbs ('always', 'sometimes') to talk about frequency.
Can-do statement.82: Can use 'very' to make adjectives stronger.
Can-do statement.83: Can use 'really' and 'very much' with verbs expressing preference ('like', 'love'), for emphasis.
Can-do statement.84: Can use a limited range of adverbs ('yesterday', 'just', 'now', 'already',) to refer to the timing of an event.
Can-do statement.85: Can use an increasing range of adverbs ('usually', 'often', 'never', 'weekly') to talk about frequency.
Can-do statement.86: Can use a limited range of degree adverbs ('so', 'quite', 'too') to modify adjectives.
Can-do statement.87: Can use a limited range of adverbs and adverb phrases ('so much', 'a lot') with verbs to indicate degree or intensity. ► determiners
Can-do statement.88: Can use a limited range of manner adverbs and adverb phrases to modify how something happens.
Can-do statement.89: Can use a limited range of adverbs ('also', 'so', 'however') to show a relationship between two clauses or sentences.
Can-do statement.90: Can use a limited range of adverbs ('only', 'just') to focus on or point to something.
Can-do statement.91: Can use a limited range of adverbs and adverb phrases ('first', 'then', 'after that') to order segments of discourse.
Can-do statement.92: Can use a limited range of adverbs ('maybe', 'perhaps') to indicate degrees of certainty.
Can-do statement.93: Can use a limited range of adverbs ('actually', 'unfortunately', 'of course', 'I’m sorry') to indicate an attitude or viewpoint.
Can-do statement.94: Can use an increasing range of adverbs to refer to the timing of an event.
Can-do statement.95: Can use an increasing range of adverbs and adverb phrases ('near', 'far away', 'upstairs', 'downstairs') to indicate place.
Can-do statement.96: Can use an increasing range of degree adverbs ('a little', 'a bit') with verbs to indicate degree or intensity. ► determiners
Can-do statement.97: Can use 'really really' with verbs and adjectives for emphasis.
Can-do statement.98: Can use an increasing range of manner adverbs and adverb phrases to modify how something happens.
Can-do statement.99: Can use an increasing range of adverbs ('therefore', 'furthermore', 'otherwise') to show a relationship between two clauses or sentences.
Can-do statement.100: Can use an increasing range of focusing adverbs ('particularly', 'especially') to point to or highlight something. ► adverbs: position
Can-do statement.101: Can use adverbs as discourse markers to organise text.  ►  adverbs: position ►  Discourse markers
Can-do statement.102: Can use an increasing range of adverbs to indicate degrees of certainty.
Can-do statement.103: Can use an increasing range of adverbs ('completely', 'obviously', 'clearly', 'actually', 'luckily', 'honestly', 'sadly', 'basically', 'obviously', 'hopefully') to indicate an attitude or viewpoint.
Can-do statement.104: Can use a wide range of adverbs and adverb phrases to refer to the timing of an event.
Can-do statement.105: Can use a wide range of manner adverbs to modify how something happpens.
Can-do statement.106: Can use a wide range of adverbs with adjectives to express degree or intensity.
Can-do statement.107: Can use a wide range of adverbs to indicate degrees of certainty.
Can-do statement.108: Can use a wide range of stance adverbs (simply, truly, surely, apparently, naturally, surprisingly, inevitably, literally, exceptionally, frankly, clearly, amazingly, wisely, admittedly) to indicate an attitude or viewpoint, often in clause initial position.
Can-do statement.109: Can use adverbs mid clause, to distance the writer from what they are saying.
Can-do statement.110: Can use 'very' to modify common gradable adjectives.
Can-do statement.111: Can use 'very' to modify time adverbs. ► adverb phrases
Can-do statement.112: Can use degree and time adverbs to modify verbs.
Can-do statement.113: Can use place adverbs ('here', 'there') as complements of verbs.
Can-do statement.114: Can use a range of degree adverbs to modify common gradable adjectives.
Can-do statement.115: Can use a limited range of manner adverbs to modify verbs.
Can-do statement.116: Can use time and sequencing adverbs to modify clauses and sentences.
Can-do statement.117: Can use a limited range of degree adverbs to modify adverbs. ► adverb phrases: form
Can-do statement.118: Can use an increasing range of manner adverbs to modify verbs.
Can-do statement.119: Can use adverbs to modify clauses and sentences to indicate stance or attitude.
Can-do statement.120: Can use degree adverbs to modify noun phrases. ► noun phrases
Can-do statement.121: Can use degree adverbs to modify pronouns. ► pronouns
Can-do statement.122: Can use degree adverbs ('almost', 'very') to modify determiners. ► determiners
Can-do statement.123: Can use an increasing range of degree adverbs to modify a range of adverb types. ► adjectives ► adverb phrases: form
Can-do statement.124: Can use degree adverbs ('slightly', 'a bit', 'much') to modify comparatives.
Can-do statement.125: Can use a limited range of degree adverbs before an adjective.
Can-do statement.126: Can use frequency adverbs in the usual mid position, between the subject and the main verb.
Can-do statement.127: Can use a limited range of adverbs in front position.
Can-do statement.128: Can use 'really' in the usual mid-position, between the subject and the main verb.
Can-do statement.129: Can use time adverbs in the usual end position.
Can-do statement.130: Can use place adverbs in the usual end position.
Can-do statement.131: Can use an increasing range of degree adverbs before an adjective.
Can-do statement.132: Can use an increasing range of adverbs in front position.
Can-do statement.133: Can use adverbs in mid position between the subject and the main verb and after modal verbs, auxiliary verbs and 'be'.
Can-do statement.134: Can use manner adverbs in the usual end position.
Can-do statement.135: Can use degree adverbs in end position.
Can-do statement.136: Can use evaluative, viewpoint and sequencing adverbs outside the clause, in front position, as a cohesive device to link to a previous statement in a preceding clause.
Can-do statement.137: Can use 'never' in front position followed by an inverted subject (most commonly 'I') + main verb verb, to give focus.
Can-do statement.138: Can use 'hardly' in front position followed by an inverted subject and verb, to give focus.
Can-do statement.139: Can use adverbs in mid position, to distance the writer from what they are saying.
Can-do statement.140: Can modify adverbs of time and degree with 'very'.
Can-do statement.141: Can modify a limited range of adverbs of time, degree, and manner with other adverbs.
Can-do statement.142: Can modify an increasing range of adverbs with other adverbs.► adverbs and adverb phrases: types and meanings
Can-do statement.143: Can modify an adverb with a comparative structure.
Can-do statement.144: Can modify a wide range of adverbs with other adverbs.
Can-do statement.145: Can post-modify adverbs with 'enough to intensify'.
Can-do statement.146: Can post-modify adverbs with a complex prepositional phrase complement, to highlight information.
Can-do statement.147: Can form adverb phrases with modifiers before, and complements after, adverbs.
Can-do statement.149: Can use 'than' + a finite clause forming the second part of a comparison after a comparative adjective
Can-do statement.150: Can use 'than' + a limited range of non-finite clauses (with -ing), forming the second part of a comparison after a comparative adjective
Can-do statement.151: Can use '(not) as' + adjective/adverb + 'as' to introduce a clause (often with a substitute auxiliary verb) to talk about two things being equal or unequal in some way.
Can-do statement.152: Can use 'rather than' + noun phrase or prepositional phrase to stress one element in a comparison.
Can-do statement.153: Can use 'the best (that)' followed by a clause with the present perfect to talk about something unique.
Can-do statement.155: Can use 'the same' (+ noun) + 'as' + pronoun or noun.
Can-do statement.157: Can use verbs of the senses + 'as if' or 'as though' + finite clause.
Can-do statement.158: Can use linking verbs + 'like' or 'similar to'.
Can-do statement.159: Can use 'than' + an increasing range of non-finite clauses (to-infinitive, reduced clause)  forming the second part of a comparison after a comparative adjective.
Can-do statement.160: Can use a superlative adjective (+ noun) (+ 'that') followed by a clause to talk about something unique.
Can-do statement.161: Can use 'enough' after adjectives followed by 'to'-infinitive.
Can-do statement.163: Can use 'rather than' + a non-finite clause to stress one element in a comparison.
Can-do statement.164: Can use 'as if' or 'as though' + finite clause to introduce a second clause as a comparison.
Can-do statement.165: Can use 'the best' as a superlative adverb + pronoun + ellipted 'can' or 'could'.
Can-do statement.166: Can use 'so' + adjective + 'as' + 'to'-infinitive clause, usually in formal contexts.
Can-do statement.167: Can use 'as if' + non-finite clause to introduce a second clause as a comparison.
Can-do statement.168: Can combine two main declarative clauses using co-ordinating conjunctions ('and', 'but', 'or').
Can-do statement.169: Can omit the subject in a second main declarative clause when the subject is obvious or the same as the first clause.
Can-do statement.170: Can combine multiple main clauses, with commas and conjunctions expressing order, often to give instructions or directions.
Can-do statement.171: Can combine multiple main clauses with a range of conjunctions, often in a narrative context.

Can-do statement.1051: Can use a limited range of verbs, typically reporting, with a 'that'-clause as the direct object.
Can-do statement.1052: Can use reporting verbs, especially mental process verbs, with a clause as the direct object, without 'that', especially in informal contexts.
Can-do statement.1053: Can use verbs, typically reporting verbs, followed by a noun or pronoun as the indirect object and a clause with or without 'that', as the direct object.
Can-do statement.1054: Can use an increasing range of verbs, typically reporting or mental process verbs, with a 'that'-clause as the direct object.
Can-do statement.1055: Can use some reporting verbs with a prepositional phrase followed by a 'that'-clause as the direct object.
Can-do statement.1056: Can use a limited range of phrasal verbs without an object.
Can-do statement.1057: Can use a limited range of phrasal verbs + object pronoun + particle.
Can-do statement.1058: Can use an increasing range of phrasal verbs without an object.
Can-do statement.1059: Can use a limited range of phrasal verbs + particle + object.
Can-do statement.1060: Can use an increasing range of phrasal verbs + object pronoun + particle.
Can-do statement.1061: Can use a wide range of phrasal verbs without an object.
Can-do statement.1062: Can use a wide range of phrasal verbs + particle + object.
Can-do statement.1063: Can use phrasal verbs + nouns as object + particle.
Can-do statement.1064: Can use a wide range of phrasal verbs + object pronoun + particle.
Can-do statement.1065: Can use regular and irregular main verbs in simple verb phrases. ► present simple ► past simple
Can-do statement.1067: Can use auxiliary verb 'be'. ►  present continuous
Can-do statement.1068: Can use a limited range of modal auxiliary verbs ('can', 'will', 'would').
Can-do statement.1070: Can use linking verbs with adjective complements.
Can-do statement.1071: Can use an increasing range of modal auxiliary verbs.
Can-do statement.1072: Can use semi-modal auxiliary verb 'have (got) to'.
Can-do statement.1073: Can use semi-modal auxiliary verbs, 'used to' and 'ought to'.
Can-do statement.1074: Can use semi-modal auxiliary verbs, 'dare' and 'need'.
Can-do statement.1075: Can use a limited range of verbs followed by a 'to'- infinitive.
Can-do statement.1076: Can use 'like' followed either by a 'to'-infinitive or an '-ing' form, with no change in meaning.
Can-do statement.1078: Can use an increasing range of verbs followed by a 'to'-infinitive.
Can-do statement.1079: Can use verbs expressing preference followed either by a 'to'-infinitive or an '-ing' form, with no change in meaning.
Can-do statement.1080: Can use 'would love to' followed by the 'to'-infinitive to give emphasis.
Can-do statement.1081: Can use 'enjoy' followed by the '-ing' form.
Can-do statement.1082: Can use a wide range of verbs followed by a 'to-' infinitive.
Can-do statement.1083: Can use 'would prefer' + 'to' infinitive, often for politeness.
Can-do statement.1084: Can use a limited range of verbs followed by an '-ing' form.
Can-do statement.1085: Can use 'help' + object + infinitive with or without 'to', with no change in meaning.
Can-do statement.1086: Can use some verbs of requesting and commanding followed by a direct object and a 'to-'infinitive.
Can-do statement.1088: Can use an increasing range of verbs followed by an '-ing' form.
Can-do statement.1089: Can introduce a new subject before the '-ing' form (using noun or object pronoun).
Can-do statement.1090: Can follow some verbs with a 'to'-infinitive or an '-ing' form, with a change in meaning.
Can-do statement.1091: Can use some verbs connected with the senses + direct object + an '-ing' form, to give emphasis to an ongoing activity.
Can-do statement.1092: Can use some verbs connected with the senses + direct object + infinitive without 'to' emphasising a complete action.
Can-do statement.1093: Can use 'would hate' + 'to' infinitive, for emphasis.
Can-do statement.1094: Can use 'there is' + singular noun phrase as complement.
Can-do statement.1095: Can use 'there are' + plural noun phrase as complement.
Can-do statement.1096: Can use 'there is' + uncountable nouns as complement.
Can-do statement.1097: Can use both 'there is' and 'there are' + 'a lot of' + plural noun.
Can-do statement.1098: Can use 'There' + 'be' + 'n't' with countable and uncountable nouns.
Can-do statement.1099: Can use 'there' with a range of modal verbs + 'be' + complement.
Can-do statement.1100: Can use 'there' with other verbs with modal meaning + 'be' + complement.
Can-do statement.1101: Can use linking verb 'be' with complements.
Can-do statement.1102: Can use an increasing range of linking verbs with complements.
Can-do statement.1103: Can use a wide range of linking verbs with complements.
Can-do statement.1104: Can form conditional subordinate clause with 'if' + present simple.
Can-do statement.1105: Can use 'if' + present simple, with an imperative in the main clause.
Can-do statement.1106: Can use 'if' + present simple with present simple, 'can' or imperative in the main clause to refer to things that are true now or very likely to happen.
Can-do statement.1107: Can use an 'if-' clause ('if you want', 'like', 'prefer') to soften the directness of imperatives, offers or suggestions.
Can-do statement.1108: Can use 'if' + present simple to introduce a possible future condition, with 'will' in the main clause to talk about a likely result.
Can-do statement.1109: Can use 'if' + present simple to introduce a possible future condition, with modal verbs in the main clause, to talk about a possible result. ► modality
Can-do statement.1110: Can use 'if' + present continuous or 'going to' to introduce a possible plan, with modal verbs or imperatives in the main clause to give advice.
Can-do statement.1111: Can form conditional subordinate clauses with 'if' + past simple, and would in the main clause, to talk about an imagined situation, often in the context of advice or opinion-giving.
Can-do statement.1112: Can use 'if I were you' and 'would' in the main clause often in the context of advice or opinion-giving.
Can-do statement.1113: Can use 'unless' + present simple to talk about an exception, with present and future reference.
Can-do statement.1114: Can form conditional subordinate clauses with 'if' + past simple, and 'could' in the main clause to talk about an imagined situation, often in the context of suggesting.
Can-do statement.1115: Can form conditional subordinate clauses with 'if' + past perfect simple and 'would have' + '-ed' in the main clause, to talk about imagined situations in the past, often with regret.
Can-do statement.1116: Can use 'If not' as a conditional clause to offer an alternative to refer to a previous direct or indirect 'yes-no' question where the answer might be 'no'.
Can-do statement.1117: Can use 'If so' as a conditional clause to refer a previous direct or indirect 'yes-no' question where the answer might be 'yes'. ► Clauses coordinated
Can-do statement.1118: Can use conditional subordinate clauses with a range of conjunctions ('as long as', 'provided') + present simple or present continuous, with future reference.
Can-do statement.1119: Can form conditional subordinate clauses with 'if' + the past perfect simple and modal verb + 'have' + '-ed' in the main clause, to talk about imagined situations in the past, often with regret.
Can-do statement.1120: Can form ellipted 'if' clauses with 'if' + '-ed' form.
Can-do statement.1121: Can form subordinate conditional clauses with 'if you should', in polite, formal contexts.
Can-do statement.1122: Can introduce a conditional subordinate clause with 'should' + inverted subject.
Can-do statement.1123: Can use inverted 'should', + 'would' in the main clause to talk about possible future outcomes, in polite or formal contexts.
Can-do statement.1124: Can use past perfect +  inverted subject, and a modal verb + 'have' + '-ed' in the main clause  to talk about imagined situations in the past.
Can-do statement.1125: Can use 'were' with an inverted subject + 'to' infinitive, to introduce conditions in formal contexts. ► past simple
Can-do statement.1126: Can use conditional subordinate clauses with a range of conjunctions ('so long as', 'on condition that', 'in the event that') with past, present or future reference.
Can-do statement.1127: Can use 'Were it not for' + noun phrase to introduce conditions in formal contexts. ► past simple
Can-do statement.1128: Can use 'If it weren't / were not for' + noun phrase to introduce conditions in formal contexts. ► past simple
Can-do statement.1129: Can use 'If it were' + 'to-' infinitive to introduce conditions in formal contexts.
Can-do statement.1130: Can use 'whether or not' to introduce conditions in formal contexts.
Can-do statement.1131: Can use 'as you know' as a discourse marker of shared knowledge.
Can-do statement.1132: Can use 'so' as a discourse marker to summarise, usually in informal contexts.
Can-do statement.1133: Can use sequencing adverbs as discourse markers to organise text.
Can-do statement.1134: Can use a range of phrases as discourse markers to introduce contrasting statements.
Can-do statement.1135: Can use a range of words and phrases as discourse markers to add information.
Can-do statement.1136: Can use 'you see', 'the thing is' as discourse markers to mark new knowledge, usually in informal contexts.
Can-do statement.1137: Can use adverbs as discourse markers to indicate an attitude or viewpoint.
Can-do statement.1138: Can use a range of phrases as discourse markers to introduce a comparison.
Can-do statement.1139: Can use a range of phrases as discourse markers to open and close texts and point to conclusions, often in formal contexts.
Can-do statement.1140: Can use a range of phrases as discourse markers to summarise.
Can-do statement.1141: Can use a range of phrases as discourse markers to point to other parts of a text.
Can-do statement.1142: Can report statements using a reporting clause with 'say' + 'that-'clause, with a pronoun shift where relevant.
Can-do statement.1143: Can report statements using a reporting clause with 'tell' + direct object + 'that-'clause, with a pronoun shift where relevant.
Can-do statement.1144: Can report statements using a reporting clause with 'say' or 'tell' + 'that-'clause, with a pronoun and tense shift where relevant.
Can-do statement.1145: Can report questions using 'ask' + 'if' or 'whether' + clause, with a pronoun and tense shift where relevant.
Can-do statement.1146: Can report 'wh-'questions using a reporting verb + 'wh-'word + clause, with a change of pronoun and tense shift where relevant.
Can-do statement.1147: Can report thought using 'wonder' + 'wh-'word + clause, with a tense shift where relevant.
Can-do statement.1148: Can report speech and thought directly, using the reporting verb before the reporting clause.
Can-do statement.1149: Can report speech and thought directly using the reporting verb after the reporting clause.
Can-do statement.1150: Can report requests and commands with 'ask' or 'tell' + direct object and 'to-'infinitive.
Can-do statement.1151: Can report speech about events in the future with and without backshifts for words relating to time.
Can-do statement.1152: Can report speech and thought directly using the reporting verb in the mid position of the reported clause.
Can-do statement.1153: Can report speech directly inverting the subject and verb in the reporting clause where the subject is a proper noun or noun phrase.
Can-do statement.1154: Can modify the reporting verb with an adverb.
Can-do statement.1155: Can report requests and commands with 'ask' or 'tell' + direct object + 'not' + 'to-'infinitive.
Can-do statement.1156: Can use the present simple form of the reporting verb to report information from a written source and a present tense verb in the reported clause.
Can-do statement.1157: Can use the past continuous of the reporting verb to report mental processes, with a finite or non-finite 'wh-'clause in the reported clause.
Can-do statement.1158: Can report speech about events in the past with backshifts for tenses and words relating to time.
Can-do statement.1159: Can use prepositional phrases in the front position for focus.
Can-do statement.1160: Can use adverbs in the front position for focus.
Can-do statement.1162: Can use 'The reason (that)', 'The place (which)' + clause as subject + 'be' for focus. ► Relative clauses
Can-do statement.1163: Can use 'The thing, fact, point, problem, or reason + is (that)' for focus.
Can-do statement.1164: Can use fixed expressions in the front position for focus.
Can-do statement.1165: Can use imperatives as pointing devices within texts for focus.
Can-do statement.1166: Can use 'What' + noun or pronoun + verb phrase as subject + 'be', for focus.
Can-do statement.1167: Can use 'Wh-'cleft clauses as titles or subtitles, to point to something that follows, for focus.
Can-do statement.1168: Can use a non-finite subordinate clause with an '-ed' form, before a main clause, for focus, often in formal, academic or business contexts.
Can-do statement.1169: Can use 'Not a' + noun with a passive verb or inverted auxiliary and subject for focus.
Can-do statement.1170: Can use 'How', 'Why', or 'Where' cleft clauses as subject, for focus
Can-do statement.1171: Can use 'The' + premodifier + 'thing, fact, point, problem or reason' + 'is (that)' for focus.
Can-do statement.1172: Can use 'It' + 'be' + noun + 'that' clause for focus.
Can-do statement.1173: Can use more than one fixed expression in the front position for added focus.
Can-do statement.1174: Can form negative statements of main verb 'be', with contracted and uncontracted forms.
Can-do statement.1175: Can form negative statements of main verbs in the present simple with 'don't' + main verb. ► present simple ► can
Can-do statement.1177: Can form negative statements of main verbs in the present continuous and present perfect with 'be' and 'have' + 'not/n't'.  ► present continuous ► present perfect
Can-do statement.1178: Can form negative statements of main verbs in the past simple with 'didn't' + main verb. ► past simple
Can-do statement.1179: Can form negative imperatives of main verbs with 'don't' + main verb. ► Clauses: imperatives
Can-do statement.1180: Can use negative forms of modal verbs. ► modal verbs
Can-do statement.1181: Can use a limited range of determiners as pronouns and indefinite pronouns in negative contexts.  ► Pronouns: quantity
Can-do statement.1182: Can use determiner 'no' with nouns.  ► Determiners: quantity
Can-do statement.1183: Can use determiners 'any', 'much' and 'many' with nouns in negative contexts. ► Determiners: quantity
Can-do statement.1184: Can form negative statements of main verbs in the past continuous and past perfect with auxiliary verbs 'be' and 'have' + 'not/n't'. ► past continuous ► past perfect
Can-do statement.1185: Can use the negative forms of mental process verbs ('I don't think', 'I don't believe') followed by a complement clause, where the negative form is in the mental process verb rather than the complement clause.
Can-do statement.1186: Can use negative question forms in main clauses and question tags. ► questions
Can-do statement.1187: Can use negative questions and question tags to involve the listener/reader by seeking agreement or checking something.
Can-do statement.1188: Can use an increasing range of indefinite pronouns in negative contexts.
Can-do statement.1189: Can use adverbs 'ever', 'never', 'yet', 'still' in negative contexts.
Can-do statement.1190: Can use 'not' before a non-finite or ellipted clause.
Can-do statement.1191: Can use uncontracted 'not' for emphasis or in formal contexts.
Can-do statement.1192: Can use 'never' in front position followed by an inverted subject (most commonly 'I') + main verb, to give focus.
Can-do statement.1193: Can use 'neither ... nor' to connect two words, phrases or clauses, often to give emphasis or focus.
Can-do statement.1194: Can use negative forms 'neither of' and 'none of' + pronoun or noun phrase with the affirmative form of the verb.
Can-do statement.1195: Can use negative pronoun 'none' to substitute for subject and object pronouns or noun phrases. ► pronouns: substitution
Can-do statement.1196: Can use 'not with indefinite pronouns 'everyone' and 'everything' and determiners 'every', 'all'.
Can-do statement.1197: Can use auxiliary 'do' + inverted subject after 'not only', to give focus.
Can-do statement.1198: Can use 'not' + stance adverb, often  in a mid position, to soften the directness of a statement.
Can-do statement.1199: Can use '(very) few' meaning 'not many' to refer to people in formal written contexts, often reports or surveys.
Can-do statement.1200: Can use 'whatsoever' after a negative form for emphasis.
Can-do statement.1201: Can use 'not a' + noun, often with a following  passive structure, for emphasis.
Can-do statement.1202: Can use a negative imperative form with 'you' to give a warning or reprimand.
Can-do statement.1203: Can use 'Neither' or 'Nor' + with 'do' or 'be' + inverted subject to add to a previous related negative clause, to focus on an additional negative factor.
Can-do statement.1204: Can use 'in the least' after a negative form for emphasis.
Can-do statement.1208: Can use the negative form of 'could' to talk about inability.
Can-do statement.1210: Can use 'could' with a limited range of verbs to make suggestions.
Can-do statement.1211: Can use the affirmative form of 'could' to talk about ability.
Can-do statement.1212: Can use 'could I' to seek permission.
Can-do statement.1213: Can use 'could' to talk about possibility.
Can-do statement.1214: Can use 'could' with an increasing range of verbs to make suggestions.
Can-do statement.1216: Can used affirmative 'could' have + '-ed' to talk about past possibility.
Can-do statement.1217: Can use 'could have' + '-ed' to speculate about the past.
Can-do statement.1218: Can use 'could have' + '-ed' to talk about regrets.
Can-do statement.1219: Can use 'could' as the past form of 'can' in reported speech.
Can-do statement.1220: Can use 'could have' + '-ed' form to express disapproval or criticism.
Can-do statement.1221: Can use 'couldn't have' + '-ed' to speculate about the past.

nan

Examples:

It seems obvious that this oil comes from the gas station. 

Computers became part of the human life style because they help us to make our lives easier, but it is clear that we should never depend on machines to handle our lives.

prompt.433:
Learn the grammar rule "Can modify adjectives with degree adverbs, often to make an assertion less direct." (MODALITY, adjectives, FORM/USE: MODIFYING ADJECTIVES, HEDGING). It is CEFR level C1. 
Examples:

prompt.434:

Learn the grammar rule "Can use the affirmative form." (MODALITY, can, FORM: AFFIRMATIVE). It is CEFR level A1.

prompt.566:

Learn the grammar rule "Can use verbs, typically reporting verbs, followed by a noun or pronoun as the indirect object and a clause with or without 'that', as the direct object." (VERBS, patterns_that clauses, FORM: VERBS + INDIRECT OBJECT CLAUSE). It is CEFR level A2.

The following day my grandpa didn?t show up.

Learn the grammar rule "Can use a wide range of phrasal verbs + particle + object. " (VERBS, phrasal, FORM: VERB + PARTICLE + OBJECT). It is CEFR level B2. Use words of high difficulty in the rule.

? it's one of the reasons I decided to change class.

Learn the grammar rule "Can use an increasing range of linking verbs with complements." (VERBS, linking, FORM: LINKING + COMPLEMENT). It is CEFR level A2. Use words of medium difficulty in the rule.

prompt.1103:
Learn the grammar rule "Can use a wide range of linking verbs with complements." (VERBS, linking, FORM: LINKING + COMPLEMENT). It is CEFR level B2. Use words of high difficulty in the rule.

Examples:

If you come to Brazil you can stay at my home.

prompt.1110:
Learn the grammar rule "Can use 'if' + present continuous or 'going to' to introduce a possible plan, with modal verbs or imperatives in the main clause to give advice." (CLAUSES, conditional, FORM/USE: PRESENT CONTINUOUS 'IF' CLAUSE , PLANS & ADVICE). It is CEFR level B1. 
Examples:

However, if you are looking for fun and excitement, I would go for the city.

In addition, if you are going to travel, please choose your partner very carefully.

Learn the grammar rule "Can form conditional subordinate clauses with 'if' + past simple, and would in the main clause, to talk about an imagined situation, often in the context of advice or opinion-giving. " (CLAUSES, conditional, FORM/USE: 'IF' + PAST SIMPLE + 'WOULD', FUTURE, IMAGINED SITUATION (SECOND CONDITIONAL)). It is CEFR level B1. 
Examples:
Maybe it would be more fun if you went with your friends. 

If you went on holiday with your friends, where would you go?

prompt.1112:
Learn the grammar rule "Can use 'if I were you' and 'would' in the main clause often in the context of advice or opinion-giving. " (CLAUSES, conditional, FORM/USE: 'IF I WERE YOU' + 'WOULD', FUTURE, IMAGINED SITUATION). It is CEFR level B1. 
Examples:
Well, if I were you I would go to a small school in the countryside because it's less complicated than going to a large school in a town.

(CLAUSES, conditional, FORM/USE: 'IF' + PAST SIMPLE + 'COULD', FUTURE, IMAGINED SITUATION). It is CEFR level B1.

(CLAUSES, conditional, FORM/USE: 'IF' + PAST PERFECT + MODAL VERBS IMAGINED SITUATION, REGRET). It is CEFR level C1.
